title: Does the past, present and future exist simultaneously? - Quora

response.answer_text: This is the common concept of time travel, but that nobody of note has checked for its logical consistency. From some nobody you can find a very detailed analysis of the contradictions, physical improbabilities and procedural impossibilities of a simultaneous existence of past, present and future can be found on the page Zeitreisen Unmöglich Endgültiger Beweis, unfortunately only in German. The site will be closed in the next months. A jpg in German will be sent to you. One big problem is the origin of that One of the core problems of assuming the existence of a past is the origin of matter. Materia would have to form anew with each layer of the past, i.e. divide or copy from nothing, which is extremely improbable. Furthermore, it would not be possible to measure time in the past. However, science can still measure time down to one attosecond, so the formation of the past would have to occur in even shorter intervals. This in turn means that in one second 1 trillion (=1 attosecond) past universes with the entire mass of the universe would have to be formed. This is extremely improbable. Then there is a structural paradox with the assumption that the three time layers would exist simultaneously. For one thing, there is a space-time layer in which everything has already happened, neither past - present nor future. There is no level from which one can look at these layers of time from above, they all exist simultaneously. LEdiglich a relative difference between two concrete points in time as sooner or later is determinable. But there would be no present, because everything would be present. Logically and conceptually, the simultaneous existence of past, present and future is not possible. But the basic paradox is the lack of a real present. Such a real present would have no future, because on this real present level reality is created in the first place. Without a real present level, a space-time model cannot explain its own creation, which makes it rather implausible. You can't claim to exist, but at the same time exclude the creation of your own existence. This is a structural paradox. If you would insert a real present into this model, you would have only one past and one real present. Within the past there would only be relative past and relative future and a subjective perceived present. The advantage of a lack of a real present is that you must not think of such questions as: How does a present copy itself into a past and how often? Where does the matter for the whole past come from ? because simply everything is already there. The core problem with the assumption of a real present, however, is that the reader's present could be the real present, which, with the absence of any reference to existing pasts or futures, in conjunction with the aforementioned extreme improbable physical facts, makes the probability assumption that there are no materially existing pasts and futures. Well, future and past simply don’t exist. It’s just the present which has meaning and existence.  How? Let’s call a moment in time as T. The time before T, which is called past, has passed and there’s no means to access, alter or live in it. Because if we somehow access it or start living in it, it becomes the present. Hence, the past ceases to exist.  Our past was future once, thus non-existent. Then it became present and started to exist. But a moment later, a new moment from future became present and the former one had to leave into non-existence. Though you can still capture the pastin your memories or in your hard drive. Similarly, future doesn’t exist until T reaches to a particular point in time. When that particular point in time is reached, the future becomes the present and starts to exist. A moment later, it becomes the past, and thus again ceases to exist.  Hence, there’s only present which exists, all time before or after that doesn’t exist, i.e, neither past nor future. We can just make assumptions for the future or could remember our past. They used to exist, when they were present at a particular point in time, but now they are not. Cheers!

Time clocks are mechanical devices which have a means for observing a rotation and a means for counting the rotations. Each clock has a means for either displaying the count or keeping a record of it. The ongoing count of these rotations is mistakenly given the title of time, which has no singular rational form of meaning. Thus the time is oxymoronic. A time is displayed by the display means. So there is no single thing which can be labeled time. The best one can do is observe these times on clocks. There is one equation in physics which insures Mother Nature is always consistent in operating a clock. It is E=hv which insures energy is transferred in fundamental processes with consistency. That equation is responsible for, at least, a minimal uncertainty of all observations. Existence assumes someone has an operating clock or there would be no means for keeping track of the rotations. Certainly the light we observe has come from somewhere in the past and there is no clock means possible for observing something that has not happened. So, everything we observe happened in the past. If the observed event is close you will not have to wait long to observe it. But, you will never observe it before it happens, because scientific method would be violated and Mother Nature would have violated cause then effect Only mathematicians are allowed to do that!

No. Your question contains the answer in the verb “does… exist,” which is present tense. Relativity theory has confused the meaning of time by making some “thing” of it (known a the error of reification.) Examples: “The fabric of space-time”… “time dilation”… “the block universe.” The past is dead and gone and the future is doesn’t exist (yet.) When “tomorrow” becomes “today” (or now), it isn’t the future anymore, which is just the concept of what has not yet happened.

When you say past, it need not necessarily mean the distant past. From a scientific perspective, a minute ago, or even a milisecond ago is also considered past. And to put things into perspective, our solar system is whizzing past the center of the Milky Way at 230 km/s, and the Earth around the Sun at 30km/s. So, if you think about it, the present is a really minute time frame sandwiched so densely between the past and the future that it overlaps. Hence, you're in the past, the present and the future at the same time.

In a way we are. From the point of view of the present, the past has already occurred, while the future may follow (branches out) any one of several potentials. Nevertheless all the versions of you in both the past, present, and future, exist as if in parallel. This is one of the effects of that common new age motto that "there is no time". Your Higher Self is simultaneously the part of your Soul that remains unaffected by incarnation, and is also the future you, after ultimately having taken all lessons and finished its journey altogether.

The past definitely exists: we see evidence of it all the time. The present seems to exist, although it is so infinitesimal, maybe it's just a thin film between past and future, i.e. an illusion. The future is the really tricky one. Does just one future exist: the one that will actually happen? Or do several potential futures exist? I think probably the latter, which preserves some semblance of free will. So the only one that exists for sure is the past. I'm not sure about either the present or the future.

Now try to capture that ‘now’ by the means of the measure units associated with the concept of time- can you? This ‘now’ that you try to seize is already gone and so is the next ‘now’ and all to follow. You can’t capture it because ‘now’ is not of time but eternal. It is only because of the concept of cause-effect, and the reliance on the wealth of concepts stored in memory that you are yanked out of the ‘now’ into the illusory realm of time and space that are the basis of the conceptual world in which you believe to exist.
